facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 73 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 73 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave against the Judgment and Order dated the 11th day of February, 1954, of the Election Tribunal, Allahabad in Election Petition No. 252 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave against the Judgment and Order dated the 11th day of February, 1954, of the Election Tribunal, Allahabad. in Election Petition No. 252 of 1952.

facts.text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh is the appellant and son of Raja Bhagwan Bux Singh of Amethi.

anchor.surface_text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh, the appellant before us, is the son of Raja Bhagwan Bux Singh of Amethi.

facts.text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh was the successful candidate at an election to the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Amethi Central constituency.

anchor.surface_text: He was the successful candidate at an election to the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Amethi  Central  companystituency

facts.text: Polling for the election took place on 31st January, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the polling in respect of which took place on the 31st January, 1952, and the result whereof was announced

facts.text: Election result was announced on 6th February, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: on the 31st January, 1952, and the result whereof was announced on the 6th February, 1952,

facts.text: Election result was published in the Uttar Pradesh State Gazette on 26th February, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1952, and the result whereof was announced on the 6th February, 1952, and finally published in the Uttar Pradesh State Gazette on the 26th February, 1952.

facts.text: Baijnath Singh, respondent, was an unsuccessful candidate and filed an election petition challenging the election of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Baijnath Singh, who was one of the unsuccessful candidates filed an election petition calling in question the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Three other unsuccessful candidates were impleaded as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Three other unsuccessful candidates were also impleaded as respondents.

facts.text: Election petition alleged corrupt practices by appellant, his servants, dependents and agents including bribery, undue influence, false statements and concealment of expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds on which the election was challenged were that the appellant himself, together with his own and his fathers servants and other dependents and agents, companymitted various companyrupt practices of bribery, exercise of undue influence, publication of false and defamatory statements and companycealment of election expenses

facts.text: Appellant denied each and every charge of corrupt practices in his written statement.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alone companytested the petition. In his written statement he denied each and every one of the charges of companyrupt practices levelled against him

facts.text: Appellant filed a petition of recrimination challenging the conduct of respondent at the election.

anchor.surface_text: and he also filed a petition of recrimination challenging the companyduct of the said respondent at the election.

facts.text: Respondent denied the charges in the recrimination petition.

anchor.surface_text: The said respondent denied the charges imputed to him.

facts.text: Election Tribunal found all 7 issues from recrimination petition against the appellant and dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: All the 7 issues arising out of the petition of recrimination were found by the tribunal companystituted for hearing of the election petition against the appellant and the petition of recrimination was dismissed.

facts.text: Election Tribunal decided issue No. 3 against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the issues arising on the main election petition the election tribunal found in favour of the appellant on issues Nos. 1, 2, 4,5, 6 and 7 but decided issue No. 3 against the appellant.

facts.text: Issue No. 3: Did respondent No. 1 employ more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. 1 incur concealed expenditures? Did he exceed prescribed limit?

anchor.surface_text: That issue was as follows3 Did respondent No. I employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. I incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other companycealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election ?

facts.text: Charges related to paragraph 6 of election petition and Part III of schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The above issue related to charges made out in paragraph 6 of the election petition and the list of particulars set out in Part III of the schedule thereto.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held against appellant on items ii and iii of first head in Part III: about 20 paid Ziladars of Amethi estate with peons and orderlies worked for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Item  ii  charred that all the paid Ziladars of Amethi estate who were about 20 in number assisted by their peons and orderlies worked for the appellant

facts.text: Item iii: Manager and Assistant Manager of Amethi estate worked for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: item No.  iii  companyplained that the Manager and the Assistant Manager of that estate also worked for him.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held that number of these persons exceeded prescribed limit and their salaries added to admitted expenses would exceed maximum permissible.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the number of all these persons companying within these two categories far exceeded the prescribed number of persons who companyld be employed in an election and their salary for the period they worked for the appellant in companynection with the election, if added to the admitted election expenses, would exceed the maximum expenditure permissible

facts.text: Election Tribunal held appellant guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(7) of Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal, therefore, held that the appellant was guilty, under both these heads, of companyrupt practice as defined, in section 123 7  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951

facts.text: Election Tribunal held appellant guilty of minor corrupt practice under section 124(4) for not showing expenses in return.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was also guilty of a minor companyrupt practice as defined in section 124 4  of the Act and was liable to be dealt with under section 100 2   a  and section 145 of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal declared the election of the appellant void.

anchor.surface_text: the tribunal under the general issue No. 8 only declared the election of the appellant to be void.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this appeal filed by the unseated candidate with the special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Maximum election expense for single-member constituency in Uttar Pradesh is Rs. 8,000 as per Schedule V.

anchor.surface_text: The maximum amount specified in that schedule in respect of a singl emember companystituency in the Uttar Pradesh is only Rs. 8,000.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the estate servants were employed and paid by the father of the appellant, not by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed number paid by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(7).

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any companyrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not guilty of minor corrupt practice under section 124(4).

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that number having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have companycealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor companyrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.

issues.text: Did respondent No. 1 employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. 1 incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other concealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election?

issues.text: Whether the Manager, Assistant Manager, Ziladars, peons and orderlies of the Amethi estate were employed for payment by the appellant or his agent in connection with the election?

holdings.text: The tribunal took the view-we think quite erroneously that although the estate belonged to the father of the appellant, nevertheless, as the appellant was the heir apparent and actually looked after the estate on behalf of the old and infirm proprietor, these servants of the estate were virtually his own servants and could properly be regarded as having been employed for payment by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was, inter alia, that the Manager, Assistant Manager, 20 Ziladars of Amethi estate and their peons and orderlies had worked for the appellant in connection with the election. The tribunal took the view-we think quite erroneously that although the estate belonged to the father of the appellant,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Servants legally employed and paid by father despite appellant managing estate; tribunal's virtual servant view erroneous.

holdings.text: Section 123(7) clearly shows that in order to amount to a corrupt practice the excess expenditure must be incurred or authorised by a candidate or his agent and the employment of extra persons must likewise be by a candidate or his agent.

anchor.surface_text: Section 123 7 clearly shows that in order -to amount -to a corrupt- practice the excess expenditure - must be incurred or authorised by a candidate or his agent and the employment of extra persons must likewise be by a candidate or his agent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of s.123(7) limits corrupt practice to actions by candidate or agent.

holdings.text: Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner consonant with section 123(7) and rule 117 and 118.

anchor.surface_text: Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner consonant with section 123 7  and rule 117 and 118. In this view of the matter the observation made by Phillimore J. in Joseph Porster Wilson and, Another v. Sir Christopher Furness 1 , relied on by the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 117/118 and s.77 follow language of s.123(7); harmonious construction required.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed nor paid by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed number paid by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal employment relation with father; assisted son at father's request like volunteers.

holdings.text: The spirit of the law may well be an elusive and unsafe guide and the supposed spirit can certainly not be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of the Act and the rules made there under.

anchor.surface_text: The spirit of the law may well be an elusive and unsafe guide and the supposed spirit can certainly not be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of the Act and the rules made there under.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain grammatical meaning prevails over purposive spirit; policy arguments to Parliament.

holdings.text: On a consideration of the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules and the arguments advanced before us we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any corrupt practice under section 123(7) as alleged against him.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any companyrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No excess employment/expenditure by appellant or agent per s.123(7).

holdings.text: It follows from this that not having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have concealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor corrupt practice under section 124(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that number having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have companycealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor companyrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No excess expenditure incurred, hence no concealment in return.

holdings.text: In the view we have taken, namely, that these extra men were not employed or paid by the appellant, it is unnecessary, for the purpose of this appeal, to discuss the question whether, if ones own servants are also utilised or employed in the conduct of the election, their salary for the period they are so utilised or employed should be regarded as election expenses and shown in the return.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken, namely, that these extra men were number employed or paid by the appellant, it is unnecessary, for the purpose of this appeal, to discuss the question whether, if ones own servants are also utilised or employed in the companyduct of the election, their salary for the period they are so utilised or employed should be regarded as election expenses and shown in the return.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue obiter as not necessary given primary holding on employment.

precedents.citation: Joseph Porster Wilson and, Another v. Sir Christopher Furness 1

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the observation made by Phillimore J. in Joseph Porster Wilson and, Another v. Sir Christopher Furness 1 , relied on by the appellant and referred to in the judgment of the tribunal are quite apposite. There can be numberdoubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed number paid by the appellant. The case, therefore, does number fall within section 123 7  at all and if that be so, it cannot companye within section 124 4 .

precedents.case_name: Joseph Forster Wilson and Another v. Sir Christopher Furness
precedents.cited_proposition: Extra persons employed and paid by the father of the candidate are in the employment of the father and not employed or paid by the candidate himself for election purposes under provisions regarding excess employment and expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules and the arguments advanced before us we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any corrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him. It follows from this that not having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have concealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to be guilty of any minor corrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant not held guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(7) or minor corrupt practice under section 124(4); tribunal's findings on excess employment, expenditure and concealment reversed, election upheld

On a consideration of the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules and the arguments advanced before us we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any corrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him. It follows from this that not having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have concealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to be guilty of any minor corrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.
